metadata.sermon_title: Wer hat dich so geschlagen? Ein Passionsgottesdienst
metadata.sermon_start_end: Wer hat dich so geschlagen, mein Heil, und dich mit Plagen so übel zugericht'? Du bist ja nicht ein Sünder wie wir und unsre Kinder, von Übeltaten weißt du nicht. Da führten sie Jesum von Kaiphas vor das Richthaus, und es war frühe. Und sie gingen nicht in [...] Christus ist wie Feuer. Von ferne betrachtet, leuchtet es, kommt man näher, so wärmt es und tröstet, geht man noch näher, so wird man selbst das Feuer.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon follows the narrative of John's Passion, but it functions more as a thematic meditation on power and victimhood than an exposition of what is unique to this specific text. The preacher uses the text as a mirror for political grievances rather than extracting a word that can be found 'nowhere else'.
quotes: Es wäre gut, die Gastarbeiter abzuschieben für das Volk.
Die Realität wahrnehmen heißt, die weitergehende Kreuzigung Jesu in unserer Welt sehen.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Identify the specific Johannine emphasis on the 'Kingship' of Christ as a theological reality rather than just a sociological category of 'the poor'.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is almost no historical-critical or linguistic exposition. The original context of the trial before Pilate is immediately bypassed to reach modern political analogies. The 'first readers' are ignored in favor of the 'zeitgeist'.
quotes: Pilatus ist ein ungebundener kritischer Intellektueller aus Rom.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the actual judicial and theological tension between the Roman 'imperium' and the Jewish 'theocracy' as presented in the Greek text.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: Application is very concrete, meeting Dekker's requirement for relevance to the zeitgeist. However, it risks becoming a political manifesto rather than a spiritual application of the Word. It names specific social groups and political issues (nuclear armament, tourism, labor).
quotes: Das philippinische Mädchen, zugerichtet für den Tourismus...
Frauen in Mutlangen bei den Massenverbrennungsanlagen Blockflöte gespielt.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Balance the political application with the 'realm of faith and faith development' so the application remains a Word of God and not just a social critique.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon succeeds in mixing the reading of the text with immediate commentary. The hearer is indeed 'drawn into the text'. However, because the 'exposition' is weak, the 'application' dominates the movement.
quotes: Heute hören wir hier die Geschichte, die täglich vor sich geht.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Ensure the 'exposition' side of the mix is grounded in the text's own logic rather than external political frameworks.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Misery is heavily emphasized, but it is primarily 'social misery' rather than 'misery before God' (sin). Redemption is equated with political resistance. Gratitude is missing as a distinct movement of the Spirit.
quotes: Ich habe dich geschlagen, Jesus. Ich unterstützte das wirtschaftliche System, das Folter braucht...
Gott ist der ganze Weg der Liebe, in jedem Augenblick.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the concept of 'misery' beyond systemic guilt to the radical lostness of the individual before God.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon presents a sharp choice: participation in the 'power of death' or the 'truth of Christ'. It addresses 'being lost in time' (social destruction). Eternal loss is absent.
quotes: Zwischen Wahrheit und Macht haben wir die Partizipation an der Macht gewählt.
In einem Unrechtsstaat ist der einzige Ort eines freien Mannes das Gefängnis.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the ultimate possibility of being lost not just to society, but to God, to increase the 'seriousness' Dekker demands.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the center, but as an ethical archetype or a co-sufferer ('the poor Galilaean') rather than the 'One Lord' who is God. The doctrine of the two natures is obscured by a focus on Christ's humanity and victimhood.
quotes: Jesus ist nicht reich, nicht aus gutem Hause, nicht griechisch gebildet, nicht weise.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Reclaim the 'telos' of Christ as God (Thesis 7) to ensure grace is 'salvation outside himself' rather than just human solidarity.

8_depth_and_length.findings: With an estimated duration of 14-15 minutes, the sermon fails Dekker's absolute minimum of 20 minutes. It lacks the 'breadth' required for true homiletical depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical and dogmatic background to allow the text to breathe beyond immediate political associations.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker’s criteria primarily due to its insufficient length and the lack of rigorous linguistic/historical exegesis. It prioritizes the 'zeitgeist' over the specific, unique content of the Bible passage. While it is concrete in application, it leans heavily toward a 'theology of the cross' that risks reducing Christ to a symbol of human suffering and political resistance, neglecting His status as the 'One Lord' and the necessity of 'salvation outside oneself'.
strengths: Concrete application: It avoids general truths and names specific contemporary sins and situations.
Interwoven structure: It successfully avoids the 'block' format of exposition followed by application.
Human-oriented: It takes the hearer's responsibility and choices seriously (Thesis 6).
weaknesses: Length: At ~15 minutes, it lacks the necessary 'breadth' for depth.
Exegetical deficit: The preacher treats the text as a springboard for social commentary rather than an object of study.
Low Christology: Christ is presented more as a victim of systems than as the incarnate God who brings redemption.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an inadequate sermon according to Dekker's theses. It functions more as a political-meditative speech than an 'exposition and application of a specific Bible passage'. It lacks the formal requirements of length and exegesis, and its substantive content is too heavily weighted toward temporal misery at the expense of Trinitarian redemption.
